content.user_title: Work with astronomical data and calculations
content.value_statement: Astronomical research requires precise handling of celestial coordinates, physical units, and specialized data formats. This skill provides expert guidance on using astropy for coordinate transformations, FITS file operations, cosmological calculations, and time scale conversions.
actual_capabilities: Transform celestial coordinates between ICRS, Galactic, FK5, and AltAz frames
Read, write, and manipulate FITS files for astronomical images and tables
Calculate cosmological distances, lookback times, and universe age
Handle time scales including UTC, TAI, TT, TDB with high precision
Perform unit conversions with physical and astronomical units
Work with tabular astronomical data and cross-match catalogs
limitations: Requires Python and astropy package installation
High-precision time calculations may require IERS data downloads
Complex coordinate transformations depend on observer location and time
Does not provide graphical visualization capabilities directly

output: Luminosity distance at z=0.5: approximately 2750 Mpc
Age of universe at this redshift: about 10.2 billion years

output_examples.input: Read a FITS file header and list all keywords with their values

best_practices: Always attach units to quantities to ensure dimensional consistency in calculations
Use context managers (with statements) when opening FITS files for safe handling
Specify time scales explicitly when working with precise astronomical times
anti_patterns: Performing coordinate transformations without verifying the input coordinate frame
Using Tables instead of QTables when columns have physical units
Modifying FITS structural keywords (SIMPLE, BITPIX, NAXIS) without understanding consequences

faq.question: Which Python version does astropy require?
faq.answer: Astropy supports Python 3.9 or later. Install with uv pip install astropy or pip install astropy.

faq.question: What is the maximum redshift for cosmological calculations?
faq.answer: Astropy calculations are valid for z less than about 5000-6000, depending on the cosmological model used.

faq.question: How do I integrate astropy with NumPy and pandas?
faq.answer: Astropy quantities work seamlessly with NumPy operations. Convert tables to pandas using Table.to_pandas() method.

faq.question: Is my data safe when reading remote FITS files?
faq.answer: Astropy can read from S3 and HTTP. Use .section for remote cutouts to avoid downloading entire files. No data leaves your environment unexpectedly.

faq.question: Why are my coordinate transformations slow?
faq.answer: Process coordinates as arrays rather than in loops. Reuse frame objects for multiple transformations. Scale conversions may require IERS data downloads.

faq.question: How does astropy compare to other astronomy libraries?
faq.answer: Astropy is the core Python astronomy library. It provides standardized tools used by most astronomy packages. CCDAstroPy builds on astropy for specific use cases.
